content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Perfect for me!
Why not ? it changes from palindromes, but then you should put number that are no palindromes, the outputs always are, you never have something like "1203", that should pass
Don’t you think "palyndromic numbers" could be an better title? It’s just a proposition, if you want to keep your actual title, you can keep it.

Goal
* Please change both occurrences of "digit(s)" to "digit".

* Please add "there is no middle digit, so" before "split".

Constraints
* Please reduce 10^5 to 10 unless you plan to add cases where [[N]] approaches the upper bound.

Cases
* Each test and its validator should cover the same scenario using similar inputs. Please revise the cases as outlined below:

  Note: Please use **random** numbers as inputs. Avoid repeatedly using numbers with consecutive digits or numbers where all digits are the same.

  • Test 1 and Validator 1: Odd number of digits, including two 3-digit integers (one balanced, one not balanced) and two 5-digit integers (one balanced, one not balanced).

  • Test 2 and Validator 2: Even number of digits, including two 2-digit integers (one balanced, one not balanced) and two 4-digit integers (one balanced, one not balanced).

  • Test 3 and Validator 3: All integers are not balanced: one 2-digit, one 3-digit, one 4-digit and one 5-digit integer.

  • Test 4 and Validator 4: Single-digit integers only.

  • Test 5 and Validator 5: Integers with 6 to 9 digits, some balanced and some not balanced.

  • Test 6 and Validator 6: Integers with 10 to 14 digits, some balanced and some not balanced.

  • Test 7 and Validator 7: Integers with 15 to 18 digits, some balanced and some not balanced.

Thanks.

In addition:

Title
* Consider deleting "and Their Balance" in the title to avoid repeating "Balance".

Cases
* Please ensure that no trailing newlines appear in inputs and outputs.

Thanks.
If you were referring to "palindromic numbers", please note that they don't involve summing up digits.

Thank you for the suggestion! I see why "Palindromic Numbers" sounds appealing because it relates to symmetry. However, the concept here is a bit different: balanced numbers are defined by the sums of digits on either side of the middle, not necessarily by being palindromes. Some balanced numbers aren’t palindromic, and some palindromes aren’t balanced. So I think the current title better reflects the actual problem, but I appreciate your input!
So can you add a test where balanced numbers are not palindromic?

Palindrome = digit symmetry
Balanced = equal sum of halves

Yes, but in all of your tests, balanced numbers are palindromic. So please add a test like this:

Input
2
1244331
124412

Output
2
1244331
124412

The balanced numbers in Test 3 are all palindromic as well. Additionally, the range of [[X]] specified in the constraint isn't fully utilised. Overall, the test case coverage is not good.

Palindromic balanced numbers can be used, but they shouldn't be the only kind of balanced numbers that are used.

I previously asked you to revise the cases in my other comment below; I'll repeat it here:

Cases
* Each test and its validator should cover the same scenario using similar inputs. Please revise the cases as outlined below:

  Note: Please use **random** numbers as inputs. Avoid repeatedly using numbers with consecutive digits or numbers where all digits are the same.

  • Test 1 and Validator 1: Odd number of digits, including two 3-digit integers (one balanced, one not balanced) and two 5-digit integers (one balanced, one not balanced).

  • Test 2 and Validator 2: Even number of digits, including two 2-digit integers (one balanced, one not balanced) and two 4-digit integers (one balanced, one not balanced).

  • Test 3 and Validator 3: All integers are not balanced: one 2-digit, one 3-digit, one 4-digit and one 5-digit integer.

  • Test 4 and Validator 4: Single-digit integers only.

  • Test 5 and Validator 5: Integers with 6 to 9 digits, some balanced and some not balanced.

  • Test 6 and Validator 6: Integers with 10 to 14 digits, some balanced and some not balanced.

  • Test 7 and Validator 7: Integers with 15 to 18 digits, some balanced and some not balanced.

Thanks.
